intro: Galium sylvaticum subsp. supinum, commonly known as creeping wood-sorrel, is a low-growing herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its prostrate growth habit, with stems that often root at the nodes. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are heart-shaped and have a distinctive reddish or purple coloration on the underside. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodland floors and stream banks.
